text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
intranets busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review the shins Port of
Mauro the shins are a Portland via
Albuquerque pop and rock band and this
is their first LP in five years and a
lot can happen in five years however on
this record I would I would not say a
lot did you know the shins have never
really been one of the boldest or most
experimental or most definitive bands in
indie rock and yet they've they've still
managed to be one of the most popular
and they're formula for success has
basically been to release a blend of
acoustic and electric rock songs that
are very straightforward accessible
their songs that kind of paint stories
and in very pastel colors and I do think
their first LP has some some nice energy
to it that kind of grabs me but I think
they toned things down a little bit on
their next two LPS and you know not to
be brutal about it but I think with
those two albums they were moving toward
making music that was just kind of
ordinary and and not completely ordinary
you know I know a Shins song when I hear
one but you know it's close enough to
that where I would be turned off despite
all this change over the years this is
the first time I'm listening to a Shin's
album where I kind of feel like I am
listening to something mature but I
might not even completely mean that in a
positive way
the mature feeling I get from this LP
comes mostly from the production while
the shins have never really written
music that ignited a fire in me you know
got me really excited or really passion
the way their music sounded had a very I
guess kind of earnest charm to it you
know I'm not saying it's it's lo-fi or
badly recorded but it was definitely the
antithesis of making music that was
overblown
however on Port of morrow I feel like
the band is kind of pulling out a lot of
stops a lot of tracks on this album
follow suit with this LPS first single
simple song which just kind of delivers
the regular shins style but with bigger
sounds and and more sheen giant chorus
vocals and arena sized drumbeats that I
could totally hear being played before
millions of the Super Bowl halftime show
or something the song fall of 82 is
another track that kind of has this very
arena sized quality to it the verse is
very understated kind of has this bar
band groove to it to it some tinny
guitar leads over and when the chorus
comes it just explodes a trumpet comes
in to back it up and okay trumpet but
overall the the hook sounds pretty nice
no way down throws a hook out to that
that kind of turns the volume up a
little bit the song bein switch does the
same but with some glassy keyboards that
kind of reminded me of Coldplay or
something and that track also has a very
quirky rhythm underneath everything with
these sequence drums that kind of make
me think of like bubbles popping some
glistening acoustic pianos on that track
too but the end result just kind of
makes me think of music I would hear
like at the mall or like in a grocery
store
of course like usual The Shins delivers
them some quieter tracks on here like
it's only life where James Mercer
actually sounds pretty passionate
singing on the verse even though the
hook is is a little generic the song for
full feels a little funky on some points
maybe I'd say it's a bit of all country
or something like that but my favorite
on this thing was definitely the final
track the title track to this album
which is very kind of dark you usually
don't hear the shins play with something
this dark Merce
singing in this in this falsetto vocal
these pianos just feels so heavy on the
track and the vocal melody is it's just
so fueled by emotional pain overall I
guess I kind of felt like this album was
okay the shins definitely brings some
some newer and bigger sounds to the
table and that may be exciting for some
older fans to hear that but I don't feel
like they brought a newer and bigger
energy to kind of fill that space which
kind of brings me back to my earlier
statement about being very mature
because to me this album feels like a
guy in his late 30s or early 40s in a
suit who just kind of forgot how to have
fun of course there are people who make
it into that age who do still know how
to have a great time or be exciting or
kind of play it loose but the shins are
so far from that it just becomes
uninteresting even though some of the
songs on here are pretty nice once you
get to know them some sweet melodies
some pretty good hooks they're not
really coming through with that strong
of a flavor or personality so I'm kind
of feeling a strong 5 to a light six on
this thing I don't see myself returning
to it outside of maybe a few tracks but
what do you guys think of it do you love
it do you hate it Harry here you go
right there
why and what should I review next
anthony Fantan oh the shins forever
